ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Carbon reduction trading scheme: charges for allocations

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The Treasury may impose charges by providing for carbon reduction trading scheme allowances to be allocated in return for payment.
The charges may only be imposed by regulations.
The regulations may make any other provision about allocations of allowances which the Treasury consider appropriate, including (in particular)—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: provision as to the imposition of fees, and as to the making and forfeiting of deposits, in connection with participation in the allocations,
provision as to the persons by whom allocations are to be conducted,
provision for allocations to be overseen by an independent person appointed by the Treasury,
provision for the imposition and recovery of penalties for failure to comply with the terms of a scheme made under subsection (4),
provision for and in connection with the recovery of payments due in respect of allowances allocated (including provision as to the imposition and recovery of interest and penalties), and

provision conferring rights of appeal against decisions made in allocations, the forfeiting of deposits and the imposition of penalties (including provision specifying the person, court or tribunal to hear and determine appeals).

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The Treasury may make schemes about the conduct and terms of allocations (to have effect subject to any regulations under this section); and schemes may in particular include provision about—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: who may participate in allocations,
the allowances to be allocated, and
where and when allocations are to take place.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In this section—

Definition_PgfTag.Definition_text: “carbon reduction trading scheme allowances” means tradeable allowances that—

DefinitionListItem.DefinitionList1_PgfTag: (a) are provided for in a relevant trading scheme, and
(b) represent the right to carry on a specified amount of activities that consist of the emission of greenhouse gas or that cause or contribute, directly or indirectly, to such emissions;

Definition_PgfTag.Definition_text: “relevant trading scheme” means a trading scheme that—

DefinitionListItem.DefinitionList1_PgfTag: (a) is made under Part 3 of the Climate Change Act 2008,
(b) applies to persons by reference to their consumption of electricity (whether or not by reference to other matters as well), and
(c) applies only to persons who consume electricity—

DefinitionListItem.DefinitionList2_PgfTag: (i) for business or charitable purposes, or
(ii) for the performance of functions of a public nature,

TextContinuation.DefinitionList1_PgfTag: (whether or not they also consume electricity for other purposes);

Definition_PgfTag.Definition_text: “specified” means specified in the relevant trading scheme.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Regulations under this section are to be made by statutory instrument.

A statutory instrument containing the first regulations under this section may not be made unless a draft of the regulations has been laid before, and approved by a resolution of, the House of Commons.

Any other statutory instrument containing regulations under this section is subject to annulment in pursuance of a resolution of the House of Commons unless a draft of the regulations has been laid before, and approved by a resolution of, that House.

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Dormant bank and building society accounts

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The Commissioners for Her Majesty’s Revenue and Customs may by regulations—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: modify section 17 of TMA 1970 (banks etc required to report interest payments) in relation to interest paid or credited in respect of a relevant dormant account,
modify Chapters 2 and 3 of Part 15 of ITA 2007 (deduction of income tax on interest payments at source) in relation to such interest, and

provide that, for the purposes of Chapter 2 of Part 4 of ITTOIA 2005 (charge to income tax on interest), such interest is to be treated as not being paid until the time (if any) at which the balance of the dormant account is paid out following a claim made by virtue of section 1(2)(b) or 2(2)(b) of the 2008 Act.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: A relevant dormant account is a dormant account the balance of which is to be, or has been, transferred—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: to an authorised reclaim fund, with the result that section 1 of the 2008 Act will apply, or applies, in relation to the account, or
to an authorised reclaim fund and one or more charities, with the result that section 2 of the 2008 Act will apply, or applies, in relation to the account.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Interest paid or credited in respect of a relevant dormant account includes interest paid or credited by a person who administers the account on behalf of an authorised reclaim fund after the balance has been transferred.
“The 2008 Act” means the Dormant Bank and Building Society Accounts Act 2008; and terms used in this section and in that Act have the same meaning in this section as in that Act.
Regulations under subsection (1) are to be made by statutory instrument.
A statutory instrument containing regulations under that subsection is subject to annulment in pursuance of a resolution of the House of Commons.

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: to an authorised reclaim fund, with the result that section 1 of the Dormant Bank and Building Society Accounts Act 2008 applies in relation to the account, or
to an authorised reclaim fund and one or more charities, with the result that section 2 of that Act applies in relation to the account.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: For the purposes of this Act—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: the transfer is not to be treated as involving any acquisition or disposal of an asset, and

the person’s rights under Part 1 of that Act are to be treated as the same asset as the original rights, acquired as the original rights were acquired and having the same characteristics as those rights.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: “The original rights” are the person’s rights against the bank or building society immediately before the transfer.
Terms used in this section and in the Dormant Bank and Building Society Accounts Act 2008 have the same meaning in this section as in that Act.”

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Homes outside UK owned through company etc

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: This Chapter does not apply to living accommodation outside the United Kingdom provided by a company for a director or other officer of the company (“D”) or a member of D’s family or household if—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: the company is wholly owned by D or D and other individuals (and no interest in the company is partnership property), and
the company has been the holding company of the property at all times after the relevant time.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The company is “the holding company of the property” when—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: it owns a relevant interest in the property,
its main or only asset is that interest, and
the only activities undertaken by it are ones that are incidental to its ownership of that interest.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The company is also “the holding company of the property” when—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: a company (“the subsidiary”) which is wholly owned by the company meets the conditions in paragraphs (a) to (c) of subsection (2),
the company’s main or only asset is its interest in the subsidiary, and
the only activities undertaken by the company are ones that are incidental to its ownership of that interest.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: “Relevant interest in the property” means an interest under the law of any territory that confers (or would but for any inferior interest confer) a right to exclusive possession of the property at all times or at certain times.
“The relevant time” is the time the company first owned a relevant interest in the property; but this is subject to subsection (6).
If—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: none of D’s interest in the company was acquired directly or indirectly from a person connected with D, and
the company owned a relevant interest in the property at the time D first acquired an interest in the company,

TextContinuation.SubSection_PgfTag: “the relevant time” is the time D first acquired such an interest.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Section 100A(1) does not apply if subsection (2), (3) or (4) applies.

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: the company’s interest in the property was acquired directly or indirectly from a connected company at an undervalue, or
the company’s interest in the property derives from an interest that was so acquired.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: This subsection applies if, at any time after the relevant time—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: expenditure in respect of the property has been incurred directly or indirectly by a connected company, or
any borrowing of the company directly or indirectly from a connected company has been outstanding (but see subsection (7)).

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: This subsection applies if the living accommodation is provided in pursuance of an arrangement the main purpose, or one of the main purposes, of which is the avoidance of tax or national insurance contributions.
In subsection (2) references to the acquisition of an interest include the grant of an interest.

For the purposes of that subsection, an interest is acquired at an undervalue if the total consideration for it is less than that which might reasonably have been expected to be obtained on a disposal of the interest on the open market; and “consideration” here means consideration provided at any time (and, for example, includes payments by way of rent).
For the purposes of subsection (3)(b), no account is to be taken of—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: any borrowing at a commercial rate, or
any borrowing which results in D being treated under Chapter 7 (taxable benefits: loans) as receiving earnings.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In subsection (4) “arrangement” includes any scheme, agreement or understanding, whether or not enforceable.
In this section “connected company” means—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: a company connected with D, with a member of D’s family or with an employer of D, or
a company connected with such a company.”

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Expenditure on provision or replacement of integral features

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: This section applies where a person carrying on a qualifying activity incurs expenditure on the provision or replacement of an integral feature of a building or structure used by the person for the purposes of the qualifying activity.
This Part (including in particular section 11(4)) applies as if—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: the expenditure were capital expenditure on the provision of plant or machinery for the purposes of the qualifying activity, and
the person who incurred the expenditure owned plant or machinery as a result of incurring it.

If the expenditure is not qualifying expenditure, whether it may be so deducted is to be determined without regard to this section.

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: an electrical system (including a lighting system),
a cold water system,
a space or water heating system, a powered system of ventilation, air cooling or air purification, and any floor or ceiling comprised in such a system,
a lift, an escalator or a moving walkway,
external solar shading.

in the period of 12 months beginning with the initial expenditure being incurred the person incurs further expenditure on the integral feature.

the amount (or the aggregate of the amounts) of the further expenditure,

TextContinuation.SubSection_PgfTag: is more than 50% of the cost of replacing the integral feature at the time the initial expenditure was incurred, this section applies to the initial expenditure and the further expenditure.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Where section 33A applies because of subsection (4), all such assessments and adjustments of assessments are to be made as are necessary to give effect to that section.”

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In relation to a transitional chargeable period, section 102 of CAA 2001 applies as if the percentage figure specified in subsection (1) of that section were x%, where—

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In subsection (2)—

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Any unrelieved qualifying expenditure in a long-life asset pool at the end of—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: a transitional chargeable period, or
a chargeable period which ends immediately before the relevant date,

TextContinuation.SubSection_PgfTag: is to be carried forward to the special rate pool.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In subsequent chargeable periods, expenditure so carried forward is to be treated for the purposes of CAA 2001 as if it were special rate expenditure carried forward in the special rate pool from the chargeable period mentioned in subsection (4).
Any unrelieved qualifying expenditure in a single asset pool at the end of—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: a transitional chargeable period, or
a chargeable period which ends immediately before the relevant date,

TextContinuation.SubSection_PgfTag: is in subsequent chargeable periods to be treated for the purposes of CAA 2001 as if it were special rate expenditure carried forward in the single asset pool from that chargeable period.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Where expenditure is treated as special rate expenditure because of this section, for the purposes of section 104E of CAA 2001—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: the reference in subsection (1)(a) of that section to section 104D of CAA 2001 includes a reference to section 102 of that Act (writing-down allowances in respect of long-life asset expenditure), and

the allowances that could have been made to the taxpayer in respect of the expenditure include allowances that could have been made under Page 44section 102 of that Act for chargeable periods before that in which the expenditure was first treated as special rate expenditure.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: A “transitional chargeable period” is one which begins before, and ends on or after, the relevant date.
“The relevant date” means—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: for corporation tax purposes, 1 April 2008, and
for income tax purposes, 6 April 2008.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Expressions used in this section and in CAA 2001 have the same meaning in this section as in that Act.
Parts 3 and 4 of CAA 2001 (industrial buildings allowances and agricultural buildings allowances) do not apply in relation to expenditure incurred on or after the relevant date.
Omit those Parts of that Act.
The amendment made by subsection (2) has effect in relation to chargeable periods beginning on or after the relevant date.
The relevant date is—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: for corporation tax purposes, 1 April 2011, and
for income tax purposes, 6 April 2011.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Schedule 27 contains amendments and savings related to this section.

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Phasing out of allowances before abolition

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: For a chargeable period to which this section applies (“a transitional chargeable period”), a person’s entitlement to a writing-down allowance under Part 3 or 4 of CAA 2001 in respect of qualifying expenditure is to be determined in accordance with this section.
This section does not apply to a writing-down allowance in respect of qualifying enterprise zone expenditure.

If the whole of a transitional chargeable period falls within a financial year listed in column 1 of the table (for corporation tax purposes) or a tax year listed in column 2 of the table (for income tax purposes), the writing-down allowance to which the person is entitled for that chargeable period is—

TextContinuation.SubSection_PgfTag: where—

ListItem.SubSection_PgfTag: WDA is the writing-down allowance to which the person would be entitled for the chargeable period apart from this section, and
P is the percentage specified in relation to that year in column 3 of the table.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: If subsection (3) does not apply in relation to a transitional chargeable period, the writing-down allowance to which the person is entitled for that chargeable period is to be determined by—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: calculating the apportioned writing-down allowance for each financial year (for corporation tax purposes) or tax year (for income tax purposes) in which part of the chargeable period falls, and
adding the amounts of the apportioned writing-down allowance for each of those years.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: For the purposes of Part 3 of CAA 2001 (industrial buildings), the apportioned writing-down allowance for a financial year or tax year in which part of a transitional chargeable period falls is—

TextContinuation.SubSection_PgfTag: where—

ListItem.SubSection_PgfTag: DCPY is the number of days in the chargeable period which fall in that year,
DCP is the number of days in the chargeable period,
WDA is the writing-down allowance to which the person would be entitled for the chargeable period apart from this section, and
P is the percentage specified in relation to that year in column 3 of the table.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: For the purposes of Part 4 of CAA 2001 (agricultural buildings), the apportioned writing-down allowance for a financial year or tax year in which part of a transitional chargeable period falls is—

TextContinuation.SubSection_PgfTag: where—

ListItem.SubSection_PgfTag: RDCPY is the number of relevant days in the chargeable period which fall in that year,
RDCP is the number of relevant days in the chargeable period,
WDA is the writing-down allowance to which the person would be entitled for the chargeable period apart from this section, and
P is the percentage specified in relation to that year in column 3 of the table.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The relevant days in the chargeable period are the days in that period for which the person was entitled to the relevant interest in relation to the qualifying expenditure (within the meaning of Part 4 of CAA 2001).

For the purposes of CAA 2001, the residue of the qualifying expenditure at any time is to be calculated as if the writing-down allowance made to a person under Part 3 or 4 of that Act in respect of the qualifying expenditure for any transitional chargeable period were the writing-down allowance which would have been made apart from this section.
This section applies—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: for corporation tax purposes, to chargeable periods which begin before the relevant date and end on or after 1 April 2008, and
for income tax purposes, to chargeable periods which begin before the relevant date and end on or after 6 April 2008.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In this section references to the table are to the following table—

Row.Cell: Financial year beginning 1 April 2007 and earlier financial years
Tax year 2007-08 and earlier tax years
Financial year beginning 1 April 2011 and later financial years
Tax year 2011-12 and later tax years

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In this section—

Definition_PgfTag.Definition_text: “the relevant date” has the same meaning as in section 81, and
“qualifying expenditure”, in relation to a writing-down allowance under Part 3 or 4 of CAA 2001, means the qualifying expenditure in respect of which the allowance is made.

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Qualifying enterprise zone expenditure: transitional provision

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: For a chargeable period which begins before, and ends on or after, the relevant date, a person’s entitlement to a writing-down allowance under Part 3 of CAA 2001 in respect of qualifying enterprise zone expenditure is to be determined in accordance with subsection (2).
The writing-down allowance to which the person is entitled is—

TextContinuation.SubSection_PgfTag: where—

ListItem.SubSection_PgfTag: DCPB is the number of days in the chargeable period which fall before the relevant date,
DCP is the number of days in the chargeable period, and
WDA is the writing-down allowance to which the person would be entitled for the chargeable period apart from this section.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In this section “the relevant date” has the same meaning as in section 81.

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Phasing out of industrial buildings allowance: anti-avoidance

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In CAA 2001, after section 313 insert—

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Calculation of allowance after sale of relevant interest: anti-avoidance

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: This section applies where—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: there is a sale of the relevant interest in the building which is a balancing event to which section 314 applies,
the buyer and seller have different chargeable periods,
the control test (within the meaning of section 567) is met, and
the purpose, or one of the main purposes, of the sale is the obtaining of a tax advantage by the buyer under this Part.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The writing-down allowance to which the buyer is entitled for the chargeable period in which the sale takes place is—

TextContinuation.SubSection_PgfTag: where—

ListItem.SubSection_PgfTag: DI is the number of days in the chargeable period for which the buyer is entitled to the relevant interest,
CP is the number of days in the chargeable period, and
WDA is the writing-down allowance to which the buyer would be entitled apart from this section.”

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The amendment made by subsection (1) has effect in relation to the sale of a relevant interest on or after 12 March 2008, except for such a sale in pursuance of a relevant pre-commencement contract (and for this purpose “sale” has the same meaning as for the purposes of Part 3 of CAA 2001).
A contract is a relevant pre-commencement contract if—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: the contract is a contract in writing made before 12 March 2008,
the contract is unconditional or its conditions have been satisfied before that date,
no terms remain to be agreed on or after that date, and
the contract is not varied in a significant way on or after that date.

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Power to make consequential and transitional provision

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The Treasury may by order make such amendments (including repeals and revocations) of enactments or instruments as may appear appropriate in consequence of, or otherwise in connection with, sections 68 to 84.
The Treasury may by order make such transitional or saving provision as may appear appropriate in consequence of, or otherwise in connection with, those sections.
An order under subsection (1) may make transitional provision and savings.
An order under subsection (1) or (2) may—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: make different provision for different cases, and
include provision having effect in relation to times before the order is made if that provision does not increase any person’s liability to tax.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: An order under subsection (1) or (2) is to be made by statutory instrument.
A statutory instrument containing an order under subsection (1) or (2) is subject to annulment in pursuance of a resolution of the House of Commons.

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Balancing allowances on transfers of trade

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: After section 343 of ICTA insert—

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Transfers of trade to obtain balancing allowances

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: This section applies where—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: a company (“the predecessor”) ceases to carry on a trade,
another company (“the successor”) begins to carry on the activities of that trade as its trade or as part of its trade,

in the accounting period in which the predecessor ceases to carry on the trade the predecessor would (apart from this section) be entitled under Part 2 of the Capital Allowances Act to a balancing allowance in respect of the trade, and
the predecessor’s ceasing to carry on the trade is part of a scheme or arrangement the main purpose, or one of the main purposes, of which is to entitle the predecessor to that balancing allowance.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: This section also applies where—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: a company (“the predecessor”) ceases to carry on part of a trade,
another company (“the successor”) begins to carry on the activities of that part of the trade as its trade or as part of its trade, and

the predecessor’s ceasing to carry on the part of the trade mentioned in paragraph (a) is part of a scheme or arrangement the main purpose, or one of the main purposes, of which is to entitle the predecessor, on cessation of the trade, to a balancing allowance in respect of the trade under Part 2 of the Capital Allowances Act.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: This section does not apply where section 343 applies.

Where this section applies, the Corporation Tax Acts have effect subject to section 343(2), but as if the words “and are subject to section 343A (company reconstructions involving business of leasing plant or machinery)” were omitted.

Where this section applies because of subsection (1), and the successor carries on the activities of the trade the predecessor ceased to carry on as part of the successor’s trade, for the purposes of section 343(2) that part of the successor’s trade is to be treated as a separate trade carried on by the successor.
Where this section applies because of subsection (2), for the purposes of section 343(2)—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: that part of the trade which the predecessor ceased to carry on is to be treated as a separate trade carried on by the predecessor, and
where the successor carries on the activities of that part of the trade as part of its trade, that part of the successor’s trade is to be treated as a separate trade carried on by the successor.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Where subsection (5) or (6) applies, such apportionment of receipts, expenses, assets and liabilities is to be made as may be just.
Section 343(10) applies to an apportionment under subsection (7) as it applies to an apportionment under section 343(9).”
The amendment made by subsection (1) has effect in relation to the cessation of a trade or part of a trade on or after 12 March 2008.

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Spreading of relief on indirect contributions

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In Part 4 of FA 2004 (pension schemes etc), after section 199 insert—

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Indirect contributions

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: This section applies where an employer (“E”)—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: pays contributions under a registered pension scheme (“the original scheme”) in a chargeable period, and
would (apart from subsection (4)) be entitled in the next chargeable period to an amount of relief in respect of a payment within subsection (2),

TextContinuation.SubSection_PgfTag: and the avoidance condition is met.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: A payment is within this subsection if all or part of the payment is intended to facilitate the payment of pension contributions under the original scheme or a substitute scheme by a person other than E.
The avoidance condition is that—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: section 197 would apply if, in the chargeable period mentioned in subsection (1)(b), E paid pension contributions under the original scheme of the amount of the relevant relief, and
the purpose, or one of the purposes, of facilitating the payment of pension contributions by a person other than E is to enable pension contributions to be paid without that section applying.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: For the purposes of the spreading provisions, the amount of the relevant relief is to be treated as the amount of a pension contribution paid by E under the original scheme in the chargeable period mentioned in subsection (1)(b).
The “relevant relief” is the relief to which the employer would (apart from subsection (4)) be entitled in that chargeable period in respect of—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: the payment within subsection (2), or
where only part of the payment is intended to facilitate the payment of pension contributions as mentioned in that subsection, that part of the payment.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: A “substitute scheme” is any registered pension scheme—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: to which there is a relevant transfer in the period of 2 years ending with the day on which the payment within subsection (2) is made, or
to which it is envisaged that a relevant transfer will or may be made after that day.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: A relevant transfer is a recognised transfer from the original scheme of more than 30% of the aggregate of—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: in a case within subsection (6)(a), the amount of the sums and the market value of the assets held for the purposes of, or representing accrued rights under, the original scheme immediately before the transfer, and
in a case within subsection (6)(b), the amount of those sums and the market value of those assets on the day on which the payment is made.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: If there is a transfer from a substitute scheme to another registered pension scheme which would have been a relevant transfer had it been a transfer from the original scheme at the time the relevant transfer was made, that other scheme is also a substitute scheme.
In subsection (1)(b), the reference to relief in respect of a payment within subsection (2) includes relief for a liability in respect of the making of the payment by a person other than E.
In this section references to E being entitled to an amount of relief are to an amount—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: being deductible in computing the amount of the profits of E for the purposes of Part 2 of ITTOIA 2005 (trading income) or Case I or II of Schedule D,
being expenses of management of E for the purposes of section 75 of ICTA (expenses of management: companies with investment business), or
being brought into account at Step 1 in section 76(7) of ICTA (expenses of insurance companies) in respect of E.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In this section—

Definition_PgfTag.Definition_text: “the spreading provisions” means sections 197 and 198 and this section, and
“chargeable period” has the meaning given by section 197.”

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The amendment made by this section has effect in relation to payments within section 199A(2) of FA 2004 made on or after 10 October 2007, except for such payments made pursuant to a contract entered into before 9 October 2007.

For section 77 substitute—

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Notifiable transactions

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: A land transaction is notifiable if it is—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: an acquisition of a major interest in land that does not fall within one or more of the exceptions in section 77A,

an acquisition of a chargeable interest other than a major interest in land where there is chargeable consideration in respect of which tax is chargeable at a rate of 1% or higher or would be so chargeable but for a relief,
a land transaction that a person is treated as entering into by virtue of section 44A(3), or
a notional land transaction under section 75A.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: This section has effect subject to—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: sections 71A(7) and 72A(7), and
paragraph 30 of Schedule 15.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In this section “relief” does not include an exemption from charge under Schedule 3.

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Exceptions for certain acquisitions of major interests in land

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The exceptions referred to in section 77(1)(a) are as follows.

Row.Cell: An acquisition which is exempt from charge under Schedule 3.

An acquisition (other than the grant, assignment or surrender of a lease) where the chargeable consideration for that acquisition, together with the chargeable consideration for any linked transactions, is less than £40,000.
The grant of a lease for a term of 7 years or more where— any chargeable consideration other than rent is less than £40,000, andthe relevant rent is less than £1,000.

The assignment or surrender of a lease where— the lease was originally granted for a term of 7 years or more, the chargeable consideration for the assignment or surrender, other than any rent, is less than £40,000, and the relevant rent is less than £1,000.
The grant of a lease for a term of less than 7 years where the chargeable consideration does not exceed the zero rate threshold.
The assignment or surrender of a lease where— the lease was originally granted for a term of less than 7 years, andthe chargeable consideration does not exceed the zero rate threshold.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Chargeable consideration for an acquisition does not exceed the zero rate threshold if it does not consist of or include—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: any amount in respect of which tax is chargeable at a rate of 1% or higher, or
any amount in respect of which tax would be so chargeable but for a relief.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In this section—

Definition_PgfTag.Definition_text: “annual rent” has the meaning given in paragraph 9A of Schedule 5,

DefinitionListItem.DefinitionList1_PgfTag: (a) the annual rent, or

(b) in the case of the grant of a lease to which paragraph 11 or 19 of Schedule 15 applies, the relevant chargeable proportion of the annual rent (as calculated in accordance with that paragraph), and

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Charge where consideration includes rent: 0% band

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Schedule 5 to FA 2003 (amount of SDLT chargeable: rent) is amended as follows.
In paragraph 9 (SDLT chargeable in respect of consideration other than rent)—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: in sub-paragraph (1), insert at the end “(but see paragraph 9A)”, and
omit sub-paragraphs (2), (2A) and (3),

TextContinuation.SubSection_PgfTag: and, accordingly, in the heading before that paragraph, insert at the end “: general”.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: After that paragraph insert—

CrossHeadingSch.CrossHeadingTitle: “Tax chargeable in respect of consideration other than rent: 0% band

SubParagraph.sch_PgfTag.SubPara.sch_text: This paragraph applies in the case of a transaction to which this Schedule applies where there is chargeable consideration other than rent.

SubParagraphCont.sch_PgfTag.SubPara.sch_text: If—

SubSubParagraph.sch_PgfTag.SubSubPara.sch_text: the relevant land consists entirely of land that is non-residential property, and
the relevant rent is at least £1,000,

TextContinuation.SubParagraphCont.sch_PgfTag: the 0% band in Table B in section 55(2) does not apply in relation to the consideration other than rent and any case that would have fallen within that band is treated as falling within the 1% band.

SubParagraphCont.sch_PgfTag.SubPara.sch_text: Sub-paragraphs (4) and (5) apply if—

SubSubParagraph.sch_PgfTag.SubSubPara.sch_text: the relevant land is partly residential property and partly non-residential property, and
the relevant rent attributable, on a just and reasonable apportionment, to the land that is non-residential property is at least £1,000.

SubParagraphCont.sch_PgfTag.SubPara.sch_text: For the purpose of determining the amount of tax chargeable under section 55 in relation to the consideration other than rent, the transaction (or, where it is one of a number of linked transactions, that set of transactions) is treated as if it were two separate transactions (or sets of linked transactions), namely—

SubSubParagraph.sch_PgfTag.SubSubPara.sch_text: one whose subject-matter consists of all of the interests in land that is residential property, and
one whose subject-matter consists of all of the interests in land that is non-residential property.

SubParagraphCont.sch_PgfTag.SubPara.sch_text: For that purpose, the chargeable consideration attributable to each of those separate transactions (or sets of linked transactions) is the chargeable consideration so attributable on a just and reasonable apportionment.
In this paragraph “the relevant rent” means—

SubSubParagraph.sch_PgfTag.SubSubPara.sch_text: the annual rent in relation to the transaction in question, or

if that transaction is one of a number of linked transactions for which the chargeable consideration consists of or includes rent, the total of the annual rents in relation to all of those transactions.

SubParagraphCont.sch_PgfTag.SubPara.sch_text: In sub-paragraph (6) the “annual rent” means the average annual rent over the term of the lease or, if—

SubSubParagraph.sch_PgfTag.SubSubPara.sch_text: different amounts of rent are payable for different parts of the term, and
those amounts (or any of them) are ascertainable at the effective date of the transaction,

TextContinuation.SubParagraphCont.sch_PgfTag: the average annual rent over the period for which the highest ascertainable rent is payable.

SubParagraphCont.sch_PgfTag.SubPara.sch_text: In this paragraph “relevant land” has the meaning given in section 55(3) and (4).”

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: After that paragraph insert—

CrossHeadingSch.CrossHeadingTitle: “Group relief not withdrawn where vendor leaves group

SubParagraph.sch_PgfTag.SubPara.sch_text: Group relief is not withdrawn under paragraph 3 where the purchaser ceases to be a member of the same group as the vendor because the vendor leaves the group.

SubParagraphCont.sch_PgfTag.SubPara.sch_text: The vendor is regarded as leaving the group if the companies cease to be members of the same group by reason of a transaction relating to shares in—

SubSubParagraph.sch_PgfTag.SubSubPara.sch_text: the vendor, or
another company that—

SubSubSubParagraph.sch_PgfTag.SubSubSubPara.sch_text: is above the vendor in the group structure, and
as a result of the transaction ceases to be a member of the same group as the purchaser.

SubParagraphCont.sch_PgfTag.SubPara.sch_text: For the purpose of sub-paragraph (2) a company is “above” the vendor in the group structure if the vendor, or another company that is above the vendor in the group structure, is a 75% subsidiary of the company.

But if there is a change in the control of the purchaser after the vendor leaves the group, paragraphs 3, 4(6) and (7), 5 and 6 have effect as if the purchaser had then ceased to be a member of the same group as the vendor.
For the purposes of this paragraph there is a change in the control of the purchaser if—

SubSubParagraph.sch_PgfTag.SubSubPara.sch_text: a person who controls the purchaser (alone or with others) ceases to do so,
a person obtains control of the purchaser (alone or with others), or
the purchaser is wound up.

SubParagraphCont.sch_PgfTag.SubPara.sch_text: For the purposes of sub-paragraph (5) a person does not control, or obtain control of, the purchaser if that person is under the control of another person or other persons.
In this paragraph references to “control” shall be interpreted in accordance with section 416 of the Taxes Act 1988 (subject to sub-paragraph (6)).”

At the end of paragraph (c) insert “and

DefinitionListItem.DefinitionList1_PgfTag: (d) a former participator to whom an amount is attributed under paragraph 2A(2) of Schedule 5 in respect of a default payment made in relation to the field in the relevant chargeable period; and

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Abandonment expenditure: default by participator met by former participator

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In Schedule 5 to OTA 1975 (allowance of expenditure, other than abortive exploration expenditure), for paragraph 2A substitute—

SubSubParagraph.sch_PgfTag.SubSubPara.sch_text: a current participator (“the defaulter”) has defaulted on a liability under—

TextContinuation.SubSubParagraph.sch_PgfTag: to make a payment towards abandonment expenditure, and

SubSubParagraph.sch_PgfTag.SubSubPara.sch_text: a current or former participator (“the contributing participator”) pays an amount in or towards meeting the whole or part of the default (“a default payment”).

SubParagraphCont.sch_PgfTag.SubPara.sch_text: If a claim is made under this Schedule for the allowance of the abandonment expenditure, the amount of the default payment is to be attributed to the contributing participator for the purposes of paragraphs 2(4)(b) and 3(1)(c).
But the amount attributed under sub-paragraph (2) may not exceed—

SubSubParagraph.sch_PgfTag.SubSubPara.sch_text: so much of the sum in default as the contributing participator is required to meet in accordance with—
such other amount as the participator may be required to meet in accordance with a direction given under Part 4 of the Petroleum Act 1998.

SubParagraphCont.sch_PgfTag.SubPara.sch_text: Sub-paragraph (2) is subject to paragraph 2B.

In determining the amount which is to be attributed to the contributing participator under sub-paragraph (2), account shall be taken of the whole of the defaulter’s interest in the relevant oil field.

But in determining the share of the abandonment expenditure to be attributed to the defaulter under paragraph 2(4)(b), the amount which would be attributed by reference to the defaulter’s interest in the relevant oil field is to be reduced or (as the case may be) extinguished by the deduction of the aggregate of—

SubSubParagraph.sch_PgfTag.SubSubPara.sch_text: the amount attributed to the contributing participator under sub-paragraph (2), and
any other amounts attributed under sub-paragraph (2) to other current or former participators who make default payments in respect of the defaulter’s default.

SubParagraph.sch_PgfTag.SubPara.sch_text: No amount is to be attributed to a contributing participator under paragraph 2A(2) unless the following conditions are all met.

SubParagraphCont.sch_PgfTag.SubPara.sch_text: The first condition is that the contributing participator is not connected with the defaulter, applying section 839 of the Taxes Act (connected persons) for the purposes of this sub-paragraph.

The second condition is that, at the end of the claim period for which the claim is made, the defaulter still has an interest in the relevant oil field which, under paragraph 2(4)(b), falls to be taken into account in determining the shares in the abandonment expenditure.
The third condition is that the relevant participators have taken all reasonable steps by way of legal remedy—

SubSubParagraph.sch_PgfTag.SubSubPara.sch_text: to secure that the defaulter meets the whole of the liability referred to in paragraph 2A(1)(a), and
to enforce any guarantee or other security provided in respect of that liability.

SubParagraphCont.sch_PgfTag.SubPara.sch_text: In sub-paragraph (4) “relevant participators” means—

SubSubParagraph.sch_PgfTag.SubSubPara.sch_text: each current participator (other than the defaulter), and
each former participator who makes a default payment in respect of the defaulter’s default.

SubParagraph.sch_PgfTag.SubPara.sch_text: An amount attributed under paragraph 2A(2) is—

SubSubParagraph.sch_PgfTag.SubSubPara.sch_text: in the case of a current participator, to be an addition to the share of the abandonment expenditure referable to the current participator’s interest in the oil field, or
in the case of a former participator, to be the share of the abandonment expenditure referable to the former participator’s interest in the oil field.

SubParagraphCont.sch_PgfTag.SubPara.sch_text: In paragraphs 2A and 2B and this paragraph—

Definition_PgfTag.Definition_text: “abandonment expenditure” means expenditure which is allowable for an oil field by virtue of section 3(1)(i) or (j);
“abandonment programme” means an abandonment programme approved under Part 4 of the Petroleum Act 1998 (including any such programme as revised);

“current participator” means a person who is, by virtue of paragraph (a), (b) or (c) of the definition in section 12, a participator in the relevant oil field in the chargeable period in which the abandonment expenditure is incurred;
“former participator” means a person who—

DefinitionListItem.DefinitionList1_PgfTag: (a) is not a current participator, but

(b) was, by virtue of paragraph (a), (b) or (c) of the definition in section 12, a participator in the relevant oil field in any chargeable period before the chargeable period in which the abandonment expenditure is incurred;

Definition_PgfTag.Definition_text: “relevant agreement” has the meaning given by section 104(5)(a) of the Finance Act 1991;
“relevant oil field” means the oil field to which the abandonment expenditure relates;
“sum in default” means the amount of the payment which the defaulter is liable to make as mentioned in paragraph 2A(1)(a), less the aggregate of—

DefinitionListItem.DefinitionList1_PgfTag: (a) so much of that payment as has been made by the defaulter, and
(b) so much of that payment as has been met by virtue of any guarantee or security provided in respect of the defaulter’s liability.

SubParagraphCont.sch_PgfTag.SubPara.sch_text: For the purposes of paragraph 2A, a current participator is to be regarded as defaulting on a liability to make a payment towards abandonment expenditure if the following conditions are met.
The first condition is that the current participator has failed to make the payment in full on the due day.
The second condition is that—

SubSubParagraph.sch_PgfTag.SubSubPara.sch_text: any of the payment remains unpaid on the sixtieth day after the due day, or

before that sixtieth day, the current participator’s interest in a relevant licence becomes liable under the relevant agreement to be sold or forfeited, in whole or in part, by reason of the failure to meet the liability.

SubParagraphCont.sch_PgfTag.SubPara.sch_text: In sub-paragraphs (4) and (5) “due day” means the day on which the payment towards abandonment expenditure becomes due under the relevant agreement or the abandonment programme.”

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The amendment made by subsection (1) has effect in relation to expenditure incurred after 30 June 2008.

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Capital allowances: plant and machinery for use in ring fence trade

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In section 52(3) of CAA 2001 (amount of first-year allowances), for the two entries in the table relating to section 45F substitute—

Row.Cell: “Expenditure qualifying under section 45F (expenditure for use wholly in a ring fence trade)

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The amendment made by subsection (1) has effect in relation to expenditure incurred on or after 12 March 2008.
Section 163 of CAA 2001 (meaning of “abandonment expenditure”) is amended as follows.
For the heading substitute “Meaning of “general decommissioning expenditure””.
For subsections (1) to (3) substitute—
Expenditure is “general decommissioning expenditure” for the purposes of sections 164 and 165 if the conditions in subsections (3) and (4) are met.
But that is subject to subsections (4ZA) to (4ZC).
The expenditure must have been incurred on decommissioning plant or machinery—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: which has been brought into use for the purposes of a ring fence trade, and
which—

SubParagraph_PgfTag.SubPara_text: is, or forms part of, an offshore installation or a submarine pipeline, or
when last in use for the purposes of a ring fence trade, was, or formed part of, such an installation or pipeline.”

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: After subsection (4) insert—
An amount of general decommissioning expenditure determined in accordance with subsection (1) is to be reduced under subsection (4ZB) if it appears that the decommissioned plant and machinery—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: was brought into use partly for the purposes of the ring fence trade and partly for the purposes of another trade, or
was brought into use wholly for the purposes of the ring fence trade, but has, at any time since, not been used wholly for those purposes.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The amount determined in accordance with subsection (1) is to be reduced to an amount which is just and reasonable having regard to the relevant circumstances.
The relevant circumstances include, in particular, the extent to which the decommissioned plant and machinery has not been used for the purposes of the ring fence trade.”
In subsection (5)(b), omit ““abandonment programme”,”.
Schedule 34 contains amendments consequential on this section.
The amendments made by this section and that Schedule have effect in relation to expenditure incurred on or after 12 March 2008.

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Capital allowances: abandonment expenditure after ceasing ring fence trade

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Section 165 of CAA 2001 (abandonment expenditure within 3 years of ceasing ring fence trade) is amended as follows.
In the heading, for “within 3 years of” substitute “after”.
For subsection (2) substitute—
“The post-cessation period” means the period that—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: begins with the day following the last day on which the former trader carried on the ring fence trade, and
ends with the day on which condition A and condition B are both met (or, if they are met on different days, the later of those days).

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Condition A is met if each approved abandonment programme that relates wholly or partly to relevant plant and machinery has ceased to have effect.
Condition B is met if the Secretary of State is satisfied that no other abandonment programmes that relate wholly or partly to relevant plant and machinery will be approved.
For the purposes of condition A, an approved abandonment programme ceases to have effect if and when—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: the programme has been carried out to the satisfaction of the Secretary of State, or
approval of the programme has been withdrawn.”

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: After subsection (4) insert—
Abandonment expenditure is to be disregarded for the purposes of this section if the expenditure is incurred in decommissioning plant and machinery at a time—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: after an abandonment programme relating wholly or partly to the plant and machinery has had its approval withdrawn, and
when no other abandonment programme relating wholly or partly to the plant and machinery is approved.”

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: After subsection (5) insert—

For the purposes of this section, it does not matter if approval of an abandonment programme that relates to relevant plant and machinery (including approval of the first such programme) is given before or after the start of the post-cessation period.
In this section—

Definition_PgfTag.Definition_text: “abandonment programme” means an abandonment programme under Part 4 of the Petroleum Act 1998;
“approved”, in relation to an abandonment programme, means approved or revised under Part 4 of the Petroleum Act 1998 (and “approval” is to be construed accordingly);
“relevant plant and machinery” means plant and machinery—

DefinitionListItem.DefinitionList1_PgfTag: (a) which has been brought into use for the purposes of the ring fence trade that has ceased, and
(b) which, when last in use for the purposes of that ring fence trade, was, or formed part of, an offshore installation or submarine pipeline;

TextContinuation.Definition_PgfTag: and for this purpose “offshore installation” and “submarine pipeline” have the same meaning as in Part 4 of the Petroleum Act 1998;

Definition_PgfTag.Definition_text: “withdrawn”, in relation to approval of an abandonment programme, means withdrawn under Part 4 of the Petroleum Act 1998.”

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Section 393A of ICTA (losses: set off against profits of the same, or an earlier, accounting period) is amended as follows.
In subsection (11)—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: for “In any case where” substitute “Subsection (11A) applies in any case where”,
in paragraph (a), for “within 3 years of” substitute “after”, and
omit the words after paragraph (b).

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: After that subsection insert—
In relation to any claim under subsection (1)—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: to the extent that the claim relates to an increase falling within subsection (11)(a), this section shall have effect as if—

SubParagraph_PgfTag.SubPara_text: in subsection (10), “the relevant period” were substituted for “the period of two years”, and
after subsection (10), there were inserted—

Row.Cell: In subsection (10), “relevant period” means the period calculated by adding two years to the post-cessation period (within the meaning of section 165 of the Capital Allowances Act).”;

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Losses: set off against profits of earlier accounting periods

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In ICTA, after section 393A insert—

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Losses of ring fence trade: set off against profits of an earlier accounting period

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: This section applies if these conditions are met—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: a company makes a claim under section 393A(1) requiring that a loss incurred in a ring fence trade be set off against profits;
section 393A(2A) applies in relation to that claim (three year set off period) by virtue of—

SubParagraph_PgfTag.SubPara_text: section 393A(2B) (loss precedes cessation of trade), or
section 393A(2C) (loss arises in year when general decommissioning expenditure incurred); and—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: the loss incurred in the ring fence trade that may be set off under section 393A (“L”) exceeds the profits against which L may be set off under section 393A (“P”).

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The profits of the ring fence trade of an accounting period are to be relieved under subsection (3) if that period—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: falls wholly or partly before the three year set off period, and
ends on or after 17 April 2002.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Subject to any relief for an earlier loss, those profits of that accounting period shall be treated as reduced by—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: the amount by which L exceeds P, or
so much of that amount as cannot be relieved under this subsection against profits of the ring fence trade of a later accounting period.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Subsection (3) is subject to subsection (5) in the case of an accounting period that falls partly (but not wholly) before the three year set off period.

The amount of the reduction of the profits of the ring fence trade that may be made under subsection (3) shall not exceed a part of those profits proportionate to the part of the accounting period that falls before the three year set off period.
Subsection (3) is subject to subsection (7) in the case of an accounting period that begins before 17 April 2002 and ends on or after that date.

The amount of the reduction of the profits of the ring fence trade that may be made under subsection (3) shall not exceed a part of those profits proportionate to the part of the accounting period that falls after 16 April 2002.
In this section—

Definition_PgfTag.Definition_text: “ring fence” has the same meaning as in section 162 of the Capital Allowances Act;
“three year set off period” means the period of three years that applies to the claim under section 393A(1) by virtue of section 393A(2A) and section 393A(2B) or (2C).”

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Schedule 35 contains minor and consequential amendments relating to the amendments made by this section.
The amendments made by this section and that Schedule have effect in relation to losses incurred in accounting periods beginning on or after 12 March 2008.

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Ring fence trade: no deduction for expenses of investment management

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In section 492 of ICTA (treatment of oil extraction activities etc for tax purposes), after subsection (3) insert—
No deduction under section 75 (expenses of management of investment business) shall be allowed from a company’s ring fence profits.”

But the deduction allowed under subsection (3) may not exceed the total amount of the expenses referable to the straddling period that have actually been paid—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: during the first portion of the straddling period, or
before the start of the straddling period.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In this section—

Definition_PgfTag.Definition_text: “first portion”, in relation to a straddling period, means the portion which—

DefinitionListItem.DefinitionList1_PgfTag: (a) begins with the first day of the straddling period, and
(b) ends with 11 March 2008,

Definition_PgfTag.Definition_text: “relevant fraction” means—

DefinitionListItem.DefinitionList1_PgfTag: P is the number of days in the first portion of the straddling period, and
T is the total number of days in the straddling period, and

Definition_PgfTag.Definition_text: “straddling period” means an accounting period beginning before 12 March 2008 and ending on or after that date.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Schedule 36 contains provision about the powers of officers of Revenue and Customs to obtain information and to inspect businesses.
That Schedule comes into force on such day as the Treasury may by order made by statutory instrument appoint.
An order under subsection (2) may contain transitional provision and savings.
This section applies to any enactment that, in connection with an HMRC matter—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: requires a person to produce a document or cause a document to be produced,
requires a person to permit the Commissioners or an officer of Revenue and Customs—

SubParagraph_PgfTag.SubPara_text: to inspect a document, or
to make or take copies of or extracts from or remove a document, or

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: makes provision about penalties or offences in connection with the production or inspection of documents, including in connection with the falsification of or failure to produce or permit the inspection of documents.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: A provision to which this section applies has effect as if—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: any reference in the provision to a document were a reference to anything in which information of any description is recorded, and

any reference in the provision to a copy of a document were a reference to anything onto which information recorded in the document has been copied, by whatever means and whether directly or indirectly.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: An authorised person may, at any reasonable time, obtain access to, and inspect and check the operation of, any computer and any associated apparatus or material which is or has been used in connection with a relevant document.
In subsection (3), “relevant document” means a document that a person has been, or may be, required pursuant to a provision to which this section applies—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: to produce or cause to be produced, or
to permit the Commissioners or an officer of Revenue and Customs to inspect, to make or take copies of or extracts from or to remove.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: An authorised person may require—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: the person by whom or on whose behalf the computer is or has been so used, or
any person having charge of, or otherwise concerned with the operation of, the computer, apparatus or material,

TextContinuation.SubSection_PgfTag: to provide the authorised person with such reasonable assistance as may be required for the purposes of subsection (3).

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Any person who—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: obstructs the exercise of a power conferred by this section, or
fails to comply within a reasonable time with a requirement under subsection (5),

TextContinuation.SubSection_PgfTag: is liable to a penalty of £300.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Paragraphs 43 to 47 and 50 of Schedule 36 (assessment of and appeals against penalties) apply in relation to a penalty under this section as they apply in relation to a penalty under paragraph 37 of that Schedule.
Omit the following—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: section 10 of FA 1985 (production of computer records etc in connection with assigned matters),
section 127 of FA 1988 (production of computer records etc in connection with the Taxes Acts), and
paragraphs 11(2) to (4) and 13(2) and (3) of Schedule 1 to the Civil Evidence Act 1995 (c. 38).

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In this section—

Definition_PgfTag.Definition_text: “authorised person” means a person who is, or is a member of a class of persons who are, authorised by the Commissioners to exercise the powers under subsection (3),
“the Commissioners” means the Commissioners for Her Majesty’s Revenue and Customs,
“enactment” includes subordinate legislation (within the meaning of the Interpretation Act 1978 (c. 30)),
“HMRC matter” means a matter in relation to which the Commissioners, or officers of Revenue and Customs, have a power or duty, and
“produce”, in relation to a document, includes furnish, deliver and any other equivalent expression.

The amendments made by that Schedule come into force on such day as the Treasury may by order made by statutory instrument appoint; and different days may be appointed for different purposes.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In paragraph 31 (amendment of return by company during enquiry), in sub-paragraph (4), for paragraph (b) substitute—

SubSubParagraph.sch_PgfTag.SubSubPara.sch_text: in any other case, the amendment takes effect as part of the amendments made by the closure notice.”

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In paragraph 34 (amendment of company tax return after enquiry), for sub-paragraphs (1) and (2) substitute—

SubParagraph.sch_PgfTag.SubPara.sch_text: This paragraph applies where a closure notice is given to a company by an officer.

make the amendments of that return that are required—

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Old VAT claims: extended time limits

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The requirement in section 80(4) of VATA 1994 that a claim under that section be made within 3 years of the relevant date does not apply to a claim in respect of an amount brought into account, or paid, for a prescribed accounting period ending before 4 December 1996 if the claim is made before 1 April 2009.

The requirement in section 25(6) of VATA 1994 that a claim for deduction of input tax be made at such time as may be determined by or under regulations does not apply to a claim for deduction of input tax that became chargeable, and in respect of which the claimant held the required evidence, in a prescribed accounting period ending before 1 May 1997 if the claim is made before 1 April 2009.
In this section—

Definition_PgfTag.Definition_text: “input tax” and “prescribed accounting period” have the same meaning as in VATA 1994 (see section 96 of that Act), and
“the required evidence” means the evidence of the charge to value added tax specified in or under regulation 29(2) of the Value Added Tax Regulations 1995 (S.I. 1995/2518).

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: This section is treated as having come into force on 19 March 2008.

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: may commence a provision generally or only for specified purposes, and

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The Treasury may by order make any incidental, supplemental, consequential, transitional, transitory or saving provision which may appear appropriate in consequence of, or otherwise in connection with, Schedule 24 to FA 2007 or Schedule 40.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The Treasury may by order make any incidental, supplemental, consequential, transitional, transitory or saving provision which may appear appropriate in consequence of, or otherwise in connection with, Schedule 41.

An order under subsection (4) may include provision amending, repealing or revoking any provision of any Act or subordinate legislation whenever passed or made (including this Act and any Act amended by it).
An order under subsection (4) may make different provision for different purposes.

A statutory instrument containing an order under subsection (4) which includes provision amending or repealing any provision of an Act is subject to annulment in pursuance of a resolution of the House of Commons.

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: HMRC decisions etc: reviews and appeals

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The Treasury may by order made by statutory instrument make provision—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: for and in connection with reviews by the Commissioners, or by an officer of Revenue and Customs, of HMRC decisions, and
in connection with appeals against HMRC decisions.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: An order under subsection (1) may, in particular, contain provision about—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: the circumstances in which, or the time within which—

SubParagraph_PgfTag.SubPara_text: a right to a review may be exercised, or
an appeal may be made, and

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: the circumstances in which, or the time at which, an appeal or review is, or may be treated as, concluded.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: An order under subsection (1) may, in particular, contain provision about the payment of sums by, or to, the Commissioners in cases where—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: a right to a review is exercised, or
an appeal is made or determined.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: That includes provision about payment of sums where an appeal has been determined, but a further appeal may be or has been made, including provision—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: requiring payments to be made,
enabling payments to be postponed, or
imposing conditions in connection with the making or postponement of payments.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: An order under subsection (1) may, in particular, contain provision about interest on any sum that is payable by, or to, the Commissioners in accordance with a decision made on the determination of an appeal.

Provision under subsection (1) may be made by amending, repealing or revoking any provision of any Act or subordinate legislation (whenever passed or made, including this Act and any Act amended by it).
An order under subsection (1) may—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: provide that any provision contained in the order comes into force on a day appointed by an order of the Treasury made by statutory instrument (and may provide that different days may be appointed for different purposes),
contain incidental, supplemental, consequential, transitional, transitory and saving provision, and
make different provision for different purposes.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: A statutory instrument containing an order under subsection (1) may not be made unless a draft of it has been laid before and approved by resolution of the House of Commons.

But if the order, or any other order under subsection (1) contained in the statutory instrument, is made in connection with a transfer of functions carried out under the Tribunals, Courts and Enforcement Act 2007 (c. 15), the statutory instrument may only be made if a draft of it has been laid before and approved by resolution of each House of Parliament.
In this section—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: references to appeals against HMRC decisions include any other kind of proceedings relating to an HMRC matter, and
references to the making, determination or conclusion of appeals are to be read accordingly.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In this section—

Definition_PgfTag.Definition_text: “the Commissioners” means the Commissioners for Her Majesty’s Revenue and Customs;
“HMRC decision” means—

DefinitionListItem.DefinitionList1_PgfTag: (a) any decision of the Commissioners relating to an HMRC matter, or
(b) any decision of an officer of Revenue and Customs relating to an HMRC matter,

TextContinuation.Definition_PgfTag: and references to an HMRC decision include references to anything done by such a person in connection with making such a decision or in consequence of such a decision;

Definition_PgfTag.Definition_text: “HMRC matter” means any matter connected with a function of the Commissioners or an officer of Revenue and Customs.

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Enforcement by taking control of goods: England and Wales

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: This section applies if a person does not pay a sum that is payable by that person to the Commissioners under or by virtue of an enactment or under a contract settlement.
The Commissioners may use the procedure in Schedule 12 to the Tribunals, Courts and Enforcement Act 2007 (c. 15) (taking control of goods) to recover that sum.
This section extends to England and Wales only.
This section applies if a person does not pay a sum that is payable by that person to the Commissioners under or by virtue of any enactment or under a contract settlement.
An officer of Revenue and Customs may apply to the sheriff for a summary warrant.
An application under subsection (2) must be accompanied by a certificate which—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: complies with subsection (4), and
is signed by the officer.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: A certificate complies with this subsection if—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: it states that—

SubParagraph_PgfTag.SubPara_text: none of the persons specified in the application has paid the sum payable by that person,
the officer has demanded payment from each such person of the sum payable by that person, and
the period of 14 days beginning with the day on which the demand is made has expired without payment being made, and

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: it specifies the sum payable by each person specified in the application.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Subsection (4)(a)(iii) does not apply to an application under subsection (2) insofar as it relates to—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: sums payable in respect of value added tax,
sums payable in respect of deductions required to be made under section 61 of FA 2004 (sub-contractors in the construction industry), and
sums payable by a person in that person’s capacity as an employer.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The sheriff must, on an application by an officer of Revenue and Customs under subsection (2), grant a summary warrant in, or as nearly as may be in, the form prescribed by Act of Sederunt.
A summary warrant granted under subsection (6) authorises the recovery of the sum payable by—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: attachment,
money attachment,
earnings arrestment,
arrestment and action of furthcoming or sale.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Subject to subsection (9) and without prejudice to section 39(1) of the Debt Arrangement and Attachment (Scotland) Act 2002 (asp 17) (expenses of attachment)—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: the sheriff officer’s fees, and
any outlays necessarily incurred by that officer,

TextContinuation.ClauseText_PgfTag: in connection with the execution of a summary warrant are to be chargeable against the person in relation to whom the warrant was granted.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: No fees are to be chargeable by the sheriff officer against the person in relation to whom the summary warrant was granted for collecting, and accounting to the Commissioners for, sums paid to that officer by that person in respect of the sum payable.
This section extends to Scotland only.
